ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: The influence of magnetic heat treatment on morphology, structure, magnetic properties of Fe-Co-P alloy films

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Key Laboratory for Magnetism and Magnetic Materials of the Ministry of Education

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: FeCoP nanocrystalline films were successfully electrodeposited on the Cu film coated silicon substrate in the bath containing Fe2+, Co2+, as well as different concentration H2PO− ions ranging from 0.001 mol/L to 0.01 mol/L. And then the samples experienced magnetic heat treatment with different heating rates. Effects of H2PO− concentration and magnetic heat treatment on morphological, structural, and magnetic properties of the films were investigated by scanning electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, vibrating sample magnetometer, and vector network analyzer. The results suggest that the as-deposited films do not exhibit obvious in-plane uniaxial magnetic anisotropy, and interestingly after magnetic heat treatment at heating rate of 6 °C/min, the FeCoP films will possess better in-plane uniaxial magnetic anisotropy. It has been obtained that morphology and grain size play important roles in determining magnetic properties. The magnetic performance of FeCoP films with different phosphorus content can be improved by appropriate magnetic heat treatment.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Soft magnetic material has been concerned in recent years, due to their potential applications on micromagnetic sensor, nanoelectric devices, and magnetic recording [1–4]. FeCo-based alloy films are attracting wide attention because of their superior soft magnetic properties, such as low coercivity, high saturation magnetic flux and high permeability at high frequency [5–8]. In order to ameliorate the soft magnetic performance of FeCo alloy films, the nonmetal element P is doped into FeCo alloy films, which also can enhance the oxidation resistance and corrosion resistance, and improve the electrical resistivity [9, 10]. So, it is very meaningful that FeCoP alloy films are used widely both in soft magnetic materials and in the area of corrosion protection. Recently, some researchers fabricated the FeCoP alloys (including nanowires [11] and films) by electrochemical methods. They showed that nanocrystalline FeCoP alloy films were formed when the P contents in the alloy films was very low [9], and with the increase of the P content, the amorphous phase gradually formed [12, 13]. The influence of the P content in the FeCoP alloy films on saturation magnetization and remanence has been studied [9, 12–14]. As for nanocrystalline FeCoP alloy films, in-plane uniaxial magnetic anisotropy is also an important property in high frequency. But up to now, there has been very little research on in-plane uniaxial magnetic anisotropy of nanocrystalline FeCoP films.

Generally, heat treatment is always used to improve the properties of the films, such as relaxing internal stress, inducing particle growth, and crystallization [11, 15, 16]. So, heat treatment with a different heating rate and annealing temperature is widely used in ceramic processes [17], optimizing catalysts [18], and semiconductor processes [19]. Magnetic alloy films also can be treated for improving magnetic performances, and simultaneously if there is an applied magnetic field during heat treatment, an in-plane uniaxial magnetic anisotropy may be induced [20]. Hence, it makes sense to study the impact of magnetic heat treatment on magnetic properties of FeCoP alloy films. In this work, we prepared the FeCoP alloy films by the electrochemical deposition technique, and heat-treated them with different heating rates under a 4000 Oe magnetic field, in order to discover potential technological applications.

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para:
In this work, different samples of Fe-Co-P alloy films with varying H2PO− ions concentration (0.001 M, 0.003 M, 0.005 M, 0.007 M, 0.01 M) in solutions were electrodeposited at room temperature, which were named sample 1, sample 2, sample 3, sample 4, and sample 5, respectively. All electrodepositions were performed by using a three-electrode potentiostatic control with a saturated calomel electrode (SEC) as reference electrode, a 1.5 cm × 1.5 cm platinum plate as the counter electrode and about 1.5 cm2 Cu coated silicon as the working electrode. The working electrodes were prepared by RF magnetron sputtering techniques. The Cu layer thickness is about 100 nm. During the process of electrodeposition, a magnetic field of 800 Oe was applied parallel to the working electrode surface for inducing in-plane magnetic anisotropy. The contents of deposition solution and operating conditions were shown in Table 1. The obtained samples were heat-treated under 4000 Oe magnetic field for 30 min at the temperature of 600 °C with the heating rate of 100 °C/min and 6 °C/min, respectively. Magnetic heat treatment was carried out in a vacuum furnace with a base pressure better than 1.0×10−4 Pa to prevent oxidation. After the treatment, the samples were cooled to room temperature in the furnace itself.

The morphology of FeCoP alloy films were monitored by the scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi S-4800, Japan) combined with energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometry (EDS). The crystalline structure of samples was investigated by X-ray diffraction using CuK
α radiation (XRD, Philips X’pert, Holland). The magnetic properties of samples were characterized using a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM, Lakeshore 7304, USA) and vector network analyzer (VNA, Agilent E8363B, USA).

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
Figure 1a–1e show SEM images of the as-deposited FeCoP alloy films with increasing P content, and present the twist rod-shaped structure formed by nanoparticles. Figures 1f and 1g show SEM images of the sample 5 after magnetic heat treatment at a heating rate of 100 °C/min and 6 °C/min to 600 °C, respectively, which obviously exhibit different morphology from untreated samples. From Fig. 1a–1e, it can be seen that the rod-shaped particles diminished in quantity. Particularly in Fig. 1e, it shows only a few rod-shaped particles and relatively uniform morphology while the P content is higher. After a magnetic heat treatment at a heating rate of 100 °C/min, the rod-shape particles disappear and the sphere-like particles as well as the pinhole defects are observed in Fig. 1f for sample 5. However, after the heat treatment at a heating rate of 6 °C/min, a compact film is obtained as shown in Fig. 1g for sample 5. And a crack appears, which is probably derived from the stress that formed during the crystallization in the process of magnetic heat treatment. The tightness of the film is related to the heating rate. It was obtained from EDS that the P content range in the FeCoP films is from 3.3 % to 5.6 % with an increase of the H2PO− ions concentration in the bath.
Fig. 1
SEM images of FeCoP films (a)–(e) fabricated at five different P content, (f) sample 5 after treatment at heating rate of 100 °C/min, (g) sample 5 after treatment at heating rate of 6 °C/min

Figure 2 shows the typical XRD patterns for sample 5 before and after magnetic heat treatments at a heating rate of 100 °C/min and 6 °C/min, respectively. The obvious diffraction peak appears at 2θ≈45°, which is corresponding with a bcc Fe–Co phase with a (110) diffraction. A small amount of P atoms may be doped into space among the crystal lattice. It can be seen that the heating rates have no obvious influence on the crystal structure although micromorphology and grain size are different for sample 5 before and after the magnetic heat treatment. Therefore, the magnetic properties of films depend to a great extent on micromorphology and grain size.
Fig. 2
X-ray diffraction patterns for sample 5 before and after treatment

Figure 3 shows the nanocrystalline grain size of FeCoP films with different P content derived using FWHM (Full Width at Half Maximum) of X-ray diffraction peak through the Scherrer equation [21, 22], which is given by
$$D = \frac{0.9\lambda}{\mathrm{FWHM} \cdot \cos \theta} $$ where D is the grain size, λ is the wavelength of X-ray, and θ is the diffraction angle. In general, the nonmetallic elements can inhibit crystallization and refine grain during electrodeposition. But apparently from Fig. 3, nanocrystalline grain size of as-deposited samples increases with the increased P content. This is because H2PO− ions in the solution are reduced on the working electrode, and then lead to the formation of OH− ions as follows:
$$\mathrm{H}_{2}\mathrm{PO}^{-} +\mathrm{e}^{-} =\mathrm{P}+2\mathrm{OH}^{-} $$ Further, higher local pH would happen at the cathode surface and inhabit hydrogen evolution, which could promote grain growth [23, 24]. After a magnetic heat treatment at a heating rate of both 100 °C/min and 6 °C/min, it is found that the grain size of FeCoP nanocrystalline films increases at first then decreases with the increased P content. During heat treatment, grain growth is promoted, but the diffusion of P atoms is encouraged simultaneously [25]. As a result of P atomic diffusion, the growth of grain is suppressed in high P content, especially on the condition of magnetic heat treatment at heating rate of 6 °C/min, which is primarily related to heat treatment time.
Fig. 3
Grain size of all samples vs. P concentration in the bath

Figure 4 shows the hysteresis loop of sample 5 before and after magnetic heat treatment at a heating rate of 100 °C/min and 6 °C/min, respectively. The magnetic properties of samples have changed enormously after treatments, and in-plane uniaxial magnetic anisotropy is typically presented in Fig. 4(c).
Fig. 4
The hysteresis loop of sample 5 before and after treatment

Figure 5 shows the coercivity Hc and remanence ratio Mr/Ms of FeCoP films along the easy axis. It can be seen that the coercivity increases and the remanence ratio decreases gradually for untreated samples with the increase of P content in the FeCoP films, which is in accordance with the grain size. After magnetic heat treatment, both the micromorphology and grain size have changed, which will result in the varying of coercivity and remanence ratio. Considering morphology and structure of the samples, the magnetic properties of samples through magnetic heat treatment are primarily based on the micromorphology in the case of high P content. In the process of magnetic heat treatment at a heating rate of 6 °C/min, the grains crystallize to better crystals due to a long-time heat treatment, thus leading to a higher magnetocrystalline anisotropy constant. So, the samples have higher coercivity and remanence ratio. As for the heating rate of 100 °C/min, the samples have low coercivity and remanence ratio because of the imperfect crystallization of grains compared to the slowly elevated-temperature magnetic heat treatment. Therefore, we could achieve an excellent in-plane uniaxial magnetic anisotropy by controlling P concentration and magnetic heat treatment together.
Fig. 5
The coercivity (a) and remanence ratio (b) of all samples vs. P concentration in the bath

Figure 6 shows the complex permeability of FeCoP films through the magnetic heat treatment at a heating rate of 6 °C/min from 100 MHz to 5 GHz using a shorted microstrip line [26]. The natural ferromagnetic resonance frequencies of the films are listed in the inset of Fig. 6. The complex permeability spectrums of samples show a very wide and low absorption peak in the frequency range from 800 MHz to 1.3 GHz. When the sample fabricated in the H2PO− ions concentration of 0.01 M and treated by magnetic heat treatment at heating rate of 6 °C/min to 600 °C, the natural resonance frequency will reach to 1.3 GHz. According to the Landua–Lifshitz–Gilbert (LLG) equation, the natural resonance frequency of ferromagnetic film is determined by in-plane uniaxial anisotropy field H
a as follows [27, 28]:
$$f_{r} = \frac{\gamma}{2\pi} \cdot \sqrt{4\pi M_{s} \cdot H_{a}} $$ where γ is the gyromagnetic ratio and M
s the saturation magnetization. The resonance frequency is a result of both saturation magnetization and in-plane uniaxial anisotropy field. The in-plane anisotropy field Ha is related to the magnetocrystalline, shape, and stress anisotropy. In this case, it is the magnetocrystalline anisotropy that plays a great role, and internal stress may also influence the in-plane anisotropy field.
Fig. 6
Complex permeability of sample 3 and sample 5 after treatment at heating rate of 6 °C/min, inset: the P concentration dependence of resonance frequency of films after treatment at heating rate of 6 °C/min

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: In summary, the influence of magnetic heat treatment and low P content in the FeCoP film on morphology, structure, and magnetic properties has been investigated. With the increase of P content in the FeCoP films, the nanocrystalline grain size increases and the films show no significant in-plane magnetic anisotropy. However, magnetic heat treatment greatly changed the properties of FeCoP films. After magnetic heat treatment, the films show excellent in-plane uniaxial magnetic anisotropy and the natural resonance frequency of samples can reach to 1.3 GHz. In this process, the grain size and micromorphology play an important role.
